title.narrative: Integrated nutrition project aimed at reducing acute malnutrition among children between 6- 59 months and pregnant and lactating women in Afmadow district, Lower Juba, Central South Somalia.

description.narrative: Afmadow district in lower Juba is one of the areas in Somalia with chronic high levels of acute malnutrition beyond the emergency threshold. It is also a district where the IDPs report high prevalence acute malnutrition(FSNAU 2017), almost 1 in every 2 children suffering from a communicable disease, limited access to health facilities, very few women with access to Maternal and child care services including delivery services (Health cluster reports) , very high morbidity rates with child illness being highest , poor access to vaccination services and 1 in every 5 pregnant or lactating women being acutely malnourished (FSNAU,2017). Most of the population are pastoral who lost their animals in the drought and still have limited pasture due to below average Gu rains(FEWSNET/FSNAU 2017) It is also an area with access constrains as per UN ratings locking some parts out out from surveys/assessments that could have provided information and humanitarian aid, even after some areas were liberated. The district outlook indicates a serious food insecurity state . The situation is unlikely to improve untill May 2017, if the Gu rains perform well. Food insecurity situation among the IDPs is in Crisis.A lot still needs to be done in this area to prevent the situation from further deterioration. WRRS therefore intends to intervene with projects that deliver lifesaving to a community ravaged by drought . Life saving to save lives of nearly 1/5 of children(Boys and girls) 6 59 months and pregnant lactating women , who are acutely malnourished and at risk of either contracting diseases or dying due to malnutrition. This will be done through scaling up treatment of moderate acute malnutrition and both complicated and uncomplicated severe acute malnutrition. To increase access additional Mobile and fixed sites will be put in place. More community health workers and volunteers will also be employed to increase access, as they hail from the community and thus frequently interact with them, offering services as needed, and appropriately referring those who need specialized assistance. They also follow up those receiving services thus promoting use of health and nutrition services. The project will use the organisation's health facilities as fixed sites , so as to encourage integration. Prevention services will also be employed as a way of reducing incidence of malnutrition. These will include provision of micro nutrient to children 6-59 months and PLWs, Nutrition Health and hygiene promotion and IYCF support . The project will work with nutrition cluster partners to avoid overlapping and with health, WASH and food security partners to link beneficiaries to those projects as much as is possible.
